_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: P1 Hallway 1 | Annual Air-Cooling Evaporator Checklist
_prev_prog_3.Description: Sandrini Sales has prepared a unified Risk & Process Safety Management Program.  The program is in compliance with California's Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program (in California CCR Title 19, Chapter 4.5 Program Level 3 Elements.  At the Federal level, Title 40 CFR Part 68), and California OSHA's "Process Safety Management (PSM) of Acutely Hazardous Materials" standard (in California CCR Title 8, Section 5189, "Process Safety Management of Acutely Hazardous Materials," and Federally Title 29 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) 1910.119).  This program has been prepared to address the risks involved with the presence of anhydrous ammonia in an amount in excess of 10,000 lbs., which is contained in our refrigeration system.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5

- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR ?68

- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR ?5189

- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR ?1910.119



Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.



This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Yosemite Cold Storage has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 



1.1 Yosemite Cold Storage, Risk and Process Safety Management Program



This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Yosemite Cold Storage has updated/developed their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following processes which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 



Process Name          |  Process Chemical           | Process Quantity(lbs.)

P1 - North System        Anhydrous Ammonia            16,000

P2 - South System        Anhydrous Ammonia             6,100





Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses, and physical property damage.



Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 

1. Prepared a unified progr

am based on the PSM regulation to meet CalARP and RMP obligations as well

2. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices

3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)



The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures, and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.



1.2 Process Descriptions



1.2.1 Facility Overview



Yosemite Cold Storage, LLC. operates a commercial cold storage facility for a variety of fruits and vegetables in Earlimart, CA. The facility has two (2) ammonia refrigeration systems that provide refrigeration capacity to the following:

(9) Rooms

(6) Precools 

(2) Hallways

(1) Loading Dock



1.2.2 Facility Location



Yosemite Cold Storage, LLC. is located at 319 S Front St, Earlimart, CA 93219. The latitude and longitude of the P1 and P2 high pressure receivers are 35.882168, -119.273491 and 35.880957, -119.273239. The facility is located approximately 0.1 miles west of state highway 99 in a rural area with agriculture land west of the facility and business/residential buildings east of the facility.



Flood Hazards



According to FEMA Flood Map Service, the facility is located in "an area of minimal flood hazard".



Seismic Susceptibility



Yosemite Cold Storage, LLC. is not located in an Alquist-Priolo Fault Zone as defined by the California Department of Conservation. In addition, a review of United States Geological Survey (USGS) fault maps revealed that there are no faults in close proximity to the site. The USGS 2018 One-Year Model revealed that Yosemite Cold Storage, LLC. has a 1-2% chance of experiencing "potentially minor-damage" due to ground shaking in 2018.



1.2.3 Description of Covered Processes



Flooded System



The refrigerated areas are equipped with air-cooling evaporators and accumulators as required for flooded operation.

Most control valve groups are located

on the roof or outside the east wall to provide easy access. The refrigeration machinery is contained within or directly outside the machinery rooms. A partial list of system components includes:

Process Chemistry



The refrigeration system employed at Yosemite Cold Storage, LLC. is configured for flooded operation. The function and thermodynamics of each major component type in the system is summarized below:



High Pressure Receiver



The purpose of the high pressure receivers is to provide a safe location to add and store high pressure liquid ammonia in the refrigeration system. The high pressure receivers receive high pressure liquid from the condensers and supply high pressure liquid to each zone of refrigeration and are also used to supply high pressure liquid to the oil cooler on the screw compressor. The high pressure receivers are also used to provide storage for ammonia not being used in the process at any given moment. Each high pressure receiver is equipped with a main liquid feed shut-off valve (king valve) that is clearly labeled and can be used to stop the flow of ammonia throughout the system. Under normal conditions, the high pressure receivers contain high pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Flooded Accumulator



The purpose of each flooded accumulator is to provide a supply of low pressure liquid ammonia to the evaporators. Each accumulator is equipped with an expansion valve which expands the high pressure liquid into a low temperature and pressure liquid as it enters the vessel. The flooded accumulators supply, by gravity, low pressure liquid to the associated evaporators. Liquid and vapor returned from the evaporators is separated inside the flooded accumulators to allow only the vapor to be returned to the main suction accumulator. Under normal conditions, the flooded accumulators contain low pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Air-Cooling Evaporators (Flooded)



The purpose of the air-cooling evaporators is to remove heat from the air in

order to maintain a predetermined space temperature. The air-cooling evaporators receive liquid from the flooded accumulator. The evaporators contain a set of continuous coils through which the low pressure liquid flows. Due to the low pressures and temperatures maintained in the evaporator, the liquid refrigerant absorbs a great deal of heat from the surrounding area and evaporates. To increase the rate of heat removed, the evaporators use an electric fan to move warm air over the coils of cold liquid ammonia. Once the liquid has evaporated to form low temperature and pressure vapor, it returns to the supplying vessel. Under normal conditions, the air-cooling evaporators contain low pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Air-Cooling Evaporators (Direct Expansion)



The purpose of the air-cooling evaporators is to remove heat from the air in order to maintain a predetermined space temperature. The air-cooling evaporators receive liquid from the high pressure receiver. Each evaporator is equipped with an expansion valve which reduces the pressure and temperature of the liquid as it enters the evaporator. The evaporators contain a set of continuous coils through which the low pressure liquid flows. Due to the low pressures and temperatures maintained in the evaporator, the liquid refrigerant absorbs a great deal of heat from the surrounding area and evaporates. To increase the rate of heat removed, the evaporators use an electric fan to move warm air over the coils of cold liquid ammonia. Once the liquid has evaporated to form low temperature and pressure vapor, it exits the evaporator and is returned to the main suction accumulator.



Main Suction Accumulators



The purpose of each main suction accumulator is to prevent liquid from entering the compressors. The main suction accumulators receive vapor from the flooded accumulators and separate any residual liquid from the vapor to allow only the vapor to be piped to the suction of each compressor. Liquid in each ma

in suction accumulator drains by gravity into the liquid transfer vessel. Each main suction accumulator is equipped with a high level float switch that is wired to shut down the compressors in the event of a high level situation. This prevents liquid ammonia from entering the compressors. Under normal conditions, the main suction accumulators contain low pressure vapor ammonia.



Liquid Transfer Vessels



The purpose of the liquid transfer vessels is to transfer liquid from the low side of the refrigeration system back to the high pressure receivers. The liquid transfer vessels receive liquid from the main suction accumulators. Once the liquid level in the liquid transfer vessels reaches the float switch, the three way solenoid valve is energized for a period of time causing the liquid transfer vessel to become subject to high pressure and activating the transfer pump which moves the liquid to the high pressure receiver. Under normal conditions the liquid transfer vessel and transfer pump can contain either high or low pressure liquid and vapor.



Compressors



The purpose of the compressors is to raise the temperature and pressure of the low pressure gas in order to reject the heat absorbed in the evaporator to the atmosphere. The compressors receive low pressure vapor from the main suction accumulator and discharge high pressure vapor to the evaporative condensers. The compressors are equipped with high discharge pressure cutouts to shut the equipment off if the pressure exceeds the setpoint. Under normal conditions, the compressors contain both high and low pressure vapor ammonia.

Evaporative Condensers



The purpose of the evaporative condensers is to reject the heat absorbed in the evaporators to the atmosphere. The evaporative condensers receive high pressure, superheated vapor from the compressors and supply high pressure liquid to the high pressure receiver. The condensers use air and water to cool the warm ammonia as it passes through a series of tube

s within the condenser. As the cooling medium of air and water draws the heat from the vapor, the refrigerant condenses into a liquid and flows to the high pressure receiver/thermosyphon vessel. Under normal conditions, the evaporative condensers contain high pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Oil Cooler



The purpose of the oil cooler is to remove heat from the oil being circulated through it. The oil cooler receives liquid from the high pressure receiver. High pressure liquid and vapor exits the oil cooler and is returned to the high pressure receiver. Under normal conditions, the oil cooler contains high pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.

Safety Systems



Ammonia Detection System



There are three standalone ammonia sensors installed at Yosemite Cold Storage, LLC. The detection system is interlocked with the refrigeration system controls as follows:

If the ammonia concentration exceeds 25 ppm, a visual and audible alarm will be activated. In addition, the PLC will notify facility personnel;

If the ammonia concentration exceeds 25 ppm, the emergency ventilation will be activated and additional horn/strobe alarms outside the machinery room will be activated.

There are two ammonia detection sample systems installed at Yosemite Cold Storage LLC. Each sample system is equipped with an ammonia detector, vacuum pump, and tubing which extends to the rooms where air is sampled. The vacuum pump is used to draw air through the tubing into the detector. On intervals, the system toggles from one sample point to the next. The sample systems provide ammonia detection to non-machinery rooms as summarized below:

North Sample System

Cold Storage Rooms 1-5

Pre-cooler Rooms A-D

Hallway

South Sample System

Cold Storage Rooms 6-9

Pre-cooler Rooms A-F



If the sample system detects an ammonia concentration exceeding 25 ppm, the system will activate an alarm and also notify plant personnel of the situation through the auto-dialer.

Emergency Control Box



The Emergenc

y Control Box (ECB) is installed on the west wall of the north machinery room and contains three (3) valves.

Valve #1: High Side Discharge Valve

Valve #2: Low Side Discharge Valve

Valve #3: High to Low Pressure Control Valve



Relief Valves



All ASME pressure vessels and positive displacement compressors are equipped with relief valves designed to relieve pressure and protect the equipment from rupturing. Details regarding the relief valves are summarized below:

Each relief valve has a set pressure equal to or less than the MAWP of the equipment that the relief valve protects;

Each relief valve has a capacity which meets or exceeds the requirement of ANSI/IIAR 2-2014 Addendum A ?15.3.8;

All relief valves are connected to a series of common manifolds which terminate to atmosphere, 7.25 ft above the roof



Screw Compressor Safety Devices



Each screw compressor has numerous safety devices to protect the compressor and the associated equipment. The following list summarizes the safety devices built into each screw compressor package:

High Discharge Pressure Cutout - The high discharge pressure cutout will shut down the compressor if the discharge pressure equals or exceeds the setpoint.

Low Suction Pressure Cutout - The low suction pressure cutout will shut down the compressor if the suction pressure is equal to or less than the setpoint.

Oil Pressure Cutout - The oil pressure cutout will shut down the compressor if the oil pressure equals or deviates below the setpoint.

High Oil Temperature Cutout - The high oil temperature cutout will shut down the compressor if the oil temperature equals or exceeds the setpoint.

Low Oil Temperature Cutout - The low oil temperature cutout will shut down the compressor if the oil temperature equals or falls below the setpoint.

Discharge Temperature Cutout - The high discharge temperature cutout will shut down the compressor if the discharge temperature equals or exceeds the setpoint.



Reciprocating Compressor Safety

Devices

Each reciprocating compressor has numerous safety devices to protect the compressor and the associated equipment. The following list summarizes the safety devices built into each compressor package:

High Discharge Pressure Cutout - The high discharge pressure cutout, will shut down the compressor if the discharge pressure equals or exceeds the setpoint.

Low Suction Pressure Cutout - The low suction pressure cutout will shut down the compressor if the suction pressure is equal to or less than the setpoint.

Oil Pressure Cutout - The oil pressure cutout will shut down the compressor if the oil pressure equals or exceeds the setpoint.



High Level Float Switches



The main suction accumulators are equipped with a high level float switch that is wired to shut down the compressors in the event of a high liquid level in the vessel. This prevents liquid ammonia from entering the compressors.



Main Liquid Feed Shut-Off Valves (King Valves)



The high pressure receivers are each equipped with a main liquid feed shut-off valve (king valve) that is clearly labeled and can be used to stop the flow of ammonia throughout their respective system.



Emergency Refrigeration Switches (E-Stops)



The principal entrance to each machinery room is equipped with an emergency refrigeration switch (e-stop) that controls power to the refrigeration machinery inside the machinery room. The switch can be activated in an emergency using the hammer next to the switch to break the switch glass.



1.2.4 Process Classification



Each ammonia refrigeration system at Yosemite Cold Storage, LLC. consists of vessels, equipment, and valves which are interconnected by piping. The systems are neither interconnected nor co-located relative to each other. As such, the refrigeration systems at Yosemite Cold Storage, LLC. are treated as two (2) independent processes.



1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps



1.3.1 General 



We inform our employees engaged in

process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meetings we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.



Yosemite Cold Storage has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 



1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia



The ammonia refrigeration process at the Yosemite Cold Storage facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.



Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep active records of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment.

  

1.4 Five Year Accident History



Yosemite Cold Storage has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.



1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan



Yosemite Cold Storage's emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:

Cal/OSHA's Emergency Action Plan - Title 8 CCR ?3220

U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Emergency Action Plans - Title 29 CFR ?1910.38

Cal/OSHA's Process Safety Management [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 8 CCR ?5189(n)

U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management [Emergency Planning and Respo

nse Requirements]- Title 29 CFR ?1910.119(n)

California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4.5 ?2765.1-2765.2

USEPA Risk Management Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 40 CFR ?68.95

California Hazardous Materials Business Plan (HMBP) [Emergency Response Plans and Procedures] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4 ?2731



Strategically, we will respond "minimally" to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 



Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.



1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Yosemite Cold Storage has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Yosemite Cold Storage continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.



By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved Yosemite Cold Storage's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that Yosemite Cold Storage's management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.



Yosemite Cold Storage has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any

time by those with access to PSMWriter.



In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Yosemite Cold Storage has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.



For the future, Yosemite Cold Storage now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Yosemite Cold Storage employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program Yosemite Cold Storage will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.
